comment.body:
Sorry, not immediately: Getting a PKEY and then querying parameters (incl pub key len) is the only pattern I know using EVP ([also perpetuated in OSSL3](https://www.openssl.org/docs/manmaster/man3/EVP_PKEY_get1_encoded_public_key.html) as far as I can tell). Only by using EC APIs directly you may do other things (didn't look into that, though as I still don't like the "concept" OQS keys == EC keys :-) 

Second thought: Isn't there a classic PKEY object "around" (to use/query) anyway when doing hybrid operations? Shouldn't the SSL connection object contain a PKEY reference/or require building one during session setup) anyway? Why is there a need to create _this_ (new) throwaway object in the first place? A cursory glance at the `ssl/statem/extensions_clnt.c` lets me think there should be PKEY objects to query (and if a hybrid PKEY, why shouldn't that contain classic size information to query)?

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,22 @@
+# OQS-ossl3
+
+This docker image contains a version of [OpenSSL3](https://github.com/openssl/openssl) built and extended with a [provider enabling quantum-safe crypto (QSC) operations](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider).
+
+To this end, it contains [liboqs](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs) as well as [OpenSSL 3/master](https://github.com/openssl/openssl) and [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider) from the [OpenQuantumSafe](https://openquantumsafe.org) project.
+
+As different images providing the same base functionality may be available, e.g., for debug or performance-optimized operations, the image name `oqs-ossl3` is consistently used in the description below. Be sure to adapt it to the image you want to use.
+
+## Quick start
+
+1) With `docker run -it oqs-ossl3` start an OQS-enabled TLS test server.
+2) On the command prompt in the docker container resulting from the first comment, one can query that server by issuing the command `openssl s_client -connect localhost --groups kyber512`. 
+
+The latter command returns all TLS information documenting use of OQS-enabled TLS. The parameter to the `--groups` argument is [any Kex Exchange algorithm supported by OQS-OpenSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl#key-exchange).
+
+## Retrieving data from other QSC-enabled TLS servers
+
+Beyond interacting with the built-in test server (utilizing `openssl s_server`) the image can also be used to retrieve data from any OQS-enabled TLS (1.3) server with the command `docker run -it oqs-ossl3 openssl s_client -connect <OQS-server address:port> --groups <suitable KEM>`.
+
+## Limitations
+
+This image is limited in functionality as per the [open issues documented for oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/issues).

pull_request.title: OpenSSL3 provider
pull_request.body:
This "dockerizes" the `oqs-provider`.
Also available is the script `fulltest/testrun.sh` to test-drive/ensure interoperability of the resultant image against `test.openquantumsafe.org`.

+import os

+# Parameter checks already done in shellscript

+with open("assignments.json", "r") as f:
+   jsoncontents = f.read();
+
+onlysigoutput = False
+if len(sys.argv)>1:
+   onlysigoutput=True
+
+assignments = json.loads(jsoncontents)
+for sig in assignments:
+    print("Testing %s:" % (sig))
+    for kem in assignments[sig]:
+       # assemble testing command
+       cmd = "(echo \'GET /\'; sleep 0.2) | ../build/tool/bssl client -connect test.openquantumsafe.org:"+str(assignments[sig][kem]) + " -root-certs CA.crt 2>&1"
+       if kem!="*": # don't prescribe KEM
+          cmd=cmd+" -curves "+kem
+       output = os.popen(cmd).read()
+       if not ("Successfully" in output):
+           print("Error with command '%s': \n%s\n" % (cmd, output))
+           if (not onlysigoutput):

pull_request.title: interop server test script added [skip ci]
pull_request.body:
Without parameters, this script executes tests against all algorithms exposed at https://test.openquantumsafe.org outputting all KEM algorithms tested. On error, testing stops.

With any parameter, this script executes tests against all algorithms exposed at https://test.openquantumsafe.org only outputting the SIG algorithms tested. On error, testing continues, outputting test command and error.

When entering it manually it works then. I'm at a loss. Please feel free to take a look in the new revision.

@@ -0,0 +1,17 @@
+#!/bin/bash
+
+if [ ! -f build/tool/bssl ]; then
+   echo "Test executable not available at 'build/tool/bssl'. Exiting."
+   exit 1
+fi
+
+rm -rf testrun && mkdir testrun && cd testrun
+
+# pull current CA cert
+wget https://test.openquantumsafe.org/CA.crt
+
+# pull list of algs/ports
+wget https://test.openquantumsafe.org/assignments.json

comment.body: It seems like the point of this script is to verify that whatever is in BoringSSL works with the interop server. Since none of the algorithms are disabled by default, why not just list them all and only test those? That would save some time and the output would be easier to understand (if the script exits with 0 errors/failures then everything in BoringSSL still works, otherwise there's something in BoringSSL that doesn't).
